data.name: textBox4.Text
data.value:
Now, let's deploy your application within the Kubernetes cluster. This involves creating a deployment, which manages a set of identical pods and ensures their availability and scalability.
Deployment Name: Enter a name for your Kubernetes deployment. This name should reflect the application or service being deployed. Example: my-app-deployment
Ports: Specify the ports that your application will expose. This enables communication with services outside the pod. Example: HTTP (80/tcp), HTTPS (443/tcp)
Container Name: Specify a name for the container within the deployment. This name is used to reference the container configuration. Example: web-server
Replicas: Specify the number of identical pod replicas you want to create. Kubernetes will manage these replicas to ensure high availability and scalability. Example: 3
Docker Image: Choose an image from a predefined list of Docker images. This image defines the application or service that each pod in the deployment will run. Example options: nginx:latest, node:14, python:3.9
Labels (Optional): Add labels to the deployment for better organization and identification. Example: app: backend, environment: production
Click Next to review your setup and complete the setup process and deploy your application.

data.name: textBox2.Text
data.value:
Let's start by setting up a new namespace where your Kubernetes resources will reside.
Namespace Name: Enter a unique name for your Kubernetes namespace. This name should be descriptive and easy to identify. Example: my-namespace
Labels (Optional): Add labels to categorize and organize your namespace. Labels are key-value pairs used for filtering and selecting resources. Example: environment: development, team: backend
Annotations (Optional): Provide additional metadata in the form of annotations. Annotations are key-value pairs used for attaching non-identifying metadata to objects. Example: created-by: John Doe, version: 1.0
Click Next to proceed to the next step.

data.name: textBox3.Text
data.value:
Now, let's create a pod within the namespace you've just set up. A pod is the smallest deployable unit in Kubernetes that represents a single instance of a containerized application.
Pod Name: Enter a name for your Kubernetes pod. This name should be unique within the namespace. Example: my-pod
Container Name: Specify a name for the container within the pod. This name is used to reference the container configuration. Example: web-server
Docker Image: Choose an image from a predefined list of Docker images. This image defines the application or service that the pod will run. Example options: nginx:latest, mysql:5.7, redis:6.0
Labels (Optional): Add labels to the pod for better organization and identification. Example: app: frontend, tier: web
Click Next to proceed to the next step.
